question: What makes Sam Altman a good founder?
reference_answer: He has a great force of will.
llm_answer: Sam Altman is considered a good founder because he has been successful in his own startup, Loopt, and is highly respected in the startup community. He is known for his determination and his ability to think in a startup-oriented way. Additionally, he has been influential in teaching others about the qualities and mindset required for success in the startup world.

reference_answer: When the startup only has three or four people.

question: What is the problem with business culture versus start up culture with respect to productivity?
reference_answer: In business culture, energy is expended on outward appearance to the detriment of productivity, while in startup culture there is no value of appearance it's all about productivity.
llm_answer: The problem with business culture versus start-up culture with respect to productivity is that conventional ideas of professionalism, which are deeply ingrained in business culture, hinder productivity. In big companies, there is often a focus on looking productive rather than actually being productive. This leads to wasted effort and less productivity. Start-up culture, on the other hand, values real productivity and focuses on generating big ideas and taking action. Start-ups are not bound by the same conventional ideas of professionalism and are able to prioritize productivity over appearances.

question: What's the single biggest thing the government could do to increase the number of startups in this country?
reference_answer: Establish a new class of visa for startup founders.
llm_answer: The government could establish a new class of visa specifically for startup founders. This would allow more startup founders to enter the country each year, which could have a visible effect on the economy and lead to a significant increase in the number of new startups being created. Additionally, by using investment by recognized startup investors as a test of whether a company is a real startup, the government can ensure that genuine startups are being supported and encouraged.

question: How could one create a rigorous government definition of what a startup is to categorize whether a business is a startup?
reference_answer: One could define a startup as a company that has received investment by recognized startup investors. An accreditation procedure would be determined to establish recognized startup investors.
llm_answer: Creating a rigorous government definition of what a startup is to categorize whether a business is a startup could be achieved by allowing the market to determine the definition. This approach would involve looking at factors such as investment by recognized startup investors as a test of whether a company qualifies as a startup. By relying on the market to define what constitutes a startup, the government can ensure that the definition remains dynamic and adaptable to the changing nature of startups.

question: Why is frienship a good quality of founders?
reference_answer: Friendship is a good quality of founders because building a startup is tough and without a strong friendship building the startup will tear the founders apart.
llm_answer: Friendship is a good quality of founders because the relationship between the founders needs to be strong. They must genuinely like one another and work well together. This is important because startups usually succeed by making something so great that people recommend it to their friends. Therefore, having a strong friendship between founders can contribute to a positive working environment and effective collaboration, ultimately increasing the chances of success for the startup.

question: Why is determination the most important quality in startup founders?
reference_answer: Because when building a startup you're going to hit a lot of obstacles, and determination will prevent one from getting demoralized by the constant obstacles.
llm_answer: Determination is considered the most important quality in startup founders because it is what drives them to succeed. While intelligence is also important, as long as founders meet a certain threshold of intelligence, determination is what sets them apart. The most successful founders are driven by their passion for their company and their project, rather than solely by the desire for money. Determination allows founders to overcome the challenges and uncertainties that come with starting a startup, and it is what keeps them motivated to pursue their goals even when faced with setbacks.

question: For startups, what does board control mean in practice?
reference_answer: During board meetings, matters are decided in the discussion preceding the vote, not in the vote itself, which is usually unanimous. If opinion is divided in such discussions, the side that knows it would lose in a vote tends to be less insistent. This is what board control means in practice.
llm_answer: Board control for startups refers to the ability of the founders to retain control over the board of directors after a series A round of funding. This means that the founders have the majority of board seats and can make decisions that are in the best interest of the shareholders. While it does not give the founders total control, it allows them to have a significant influence on the direction and decision-making of the company.
retrieved_context:
["That's what board control means in practice.", 'Which means if it becomes the norm for founders to retain board control after a series A, that will change the way things feel in the whole startup world.', "and asked me how common it was for a startup's founders to retain control of the board after a series A round.", 'Knowing that founders will keep control of the board may even help VCs pick better.', 'A lot of VCs still act as if founders retaining board control after a series A is unheard-of.', "then your opinion about what's in the interest of the shareholders will tend to prevail.So while board control is not total control, it's not imaginary either.", 'Control of a company is a more complicated matter than simply outvoting other parties in board meetings.', 'In the past, founders rarely kept control of the board through a series A.', 'But are these just outliers?How common is it for founders to keep control after an A round?', 'Founders retaining control after a series A is clearly heard-of.And barring financial catastrophe, I think in the coming year it will become the norm.', 'The switch to the new norm may be surprisingly fast, because the startups that can retain control tend to be the best ones.', "A lot of them don't care that much personally about whether founders keep board control.They just don't want to seem like they had to make concessions.", 'The traditional series A board consisted of two founders, two VCs, and one independent member.', "In a dozen companies we've funded, the founders still had a majority of the board seats after the series A round.", 'Founder Control

question: What's in the way of founders keeping board control after a series A?
reference_answer: The perception that founders keeping board control after a series A being a concession a VC has made when negotiating with startups. VCs do not want to look like they've lost a negotiation. If founders keeping control after a series A is the norm, then it happening will not look like the VCs lost the negotiation.
llm_answer: The traditional structure of a series A board, consisting of two founders, two VCs, and one independent member, often results in founders losing their majority control. However, in some cases, founders are able to retain control of the board even after a series A round. The resistance to founders keeping board control may stem from VCs not wanting to appear as if they had to make concessions. However, if the perception of letting founders keep control changes, it is likely to become more common for founders to retain board control after a series A.
